awd_titl_txt: Theoretical Understanding of Porosity-Induced Mechanisms during Solidification of Cast Alloys and their Influence on Process-Structure-Property Correlations
awd_abstract_narration:
Casting is a process in which liquid metal is poured into a mold and then allowed to cool and solidify. Cast alloys are used in many diverse applications, ranging from automotive parts to aerospace components. Porosity that arises during the solidification process has long been recognized as a critical factor in limiting the mechanical performance of cast alloys, especially under repetitive use that results in "fatigue" behavior. There is a strong drive towards minimizing porosity through a combination of casting design and optimization of the solidification process. To achieve that, a fundamental understanding of the underlying physics of porosity formation, growth and mobility and its impact on fatigue, and an enhanced predictive capability become necessary. This research addresses these needs through theoretical and computational modeling of processing and behavior at multiple length scales. Results from this research will lead to time- and cost-effective design and optimization processes that automotive, aerospace, and other industries can utilize to obtain better alloys and alloy components. This research features a synergistic approach based on materials science, manufacturing, and computational mechanics, which will expose graduate students to broader concepts and skills. Active focus will be given to ensure participation of underrepresented undergraduate students in research and outreach to high school students will strive to inspire interest in engineering education from an early age.

The objective of this research is to acquire a fundamental understanding of the mechanisms that govern porosity nucleation, growth, and migration during directional solidification process and employ that understanding to identify process-structure-property relations in cast alloys. This objective will be accomplished based on analysis and interpretation of existing solidification experimental data using theoretical and computational tools. Competing and contributing mechanisms that control porosity nucleation (solidification shrinkage and hydrogen segregation), growth (hydrogen diffusion, solidification front grow, and dendritic growth), and migration (buoyancy and thermocapillary effects) will be theorized and modeled. The multiscale computational framework, which will consist of a developed phase-field model and an existing internal state variable model combined with first-principles calculations, crystal plasticity, and the finite element method, will enable a phenomenological interpretation of the solidification process at multiple length scales. The accumulated constitutive descriptions will then be used to develop process-structure-property correlations.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: MSU- Center for Advanced Vehicular Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The overarching goal of the project is to acquire a fundamental understanding of the competing mechanisms that govern the porosity nucleation, growth, and migration during directional solidification (DS) process and employ that understanding to identify process-structure-property-performance relations of cast alloys. This goal was accomplished based on analysis and interpretation of existing DS experimental data using tools of computational continuum mechanics, crystal physics, and multiscale modeling.  Specific outcomes of this work are:

  • A validated multiscale computational framework which includes a FE-based internal state variable (ISV) plasticity model and a FE-based thermal model at the macroscale and a temperature-dependent grain growth phase-field model and fast Fourier transform-based elasto-viscoplastic (EVP-FFT) micromechanical model at the mesoscale for studying and predicting the predict the microstructure evolutions of metallic and ceramic polymer composite materials during additive manufacturing processes.
  • Using this multiscale framework, process-structure-property relationships of AM-produced Ti-6Al-4V alloy, Al-Si-Mg alloy, and TPC piezocomposite, as well as the precipitation kinetics in INCONEL 625 have been studied in conjunction with necessary experimental investigations.
  • A novel deep learning (DL) based multistage StackGAN methodology has been developed for the reconstruction of synthetic microstructures of additively manufactured piezoceramics. The developed method is an effective and powerful tool in investigating the structure-property-performance relationship of peizoelectric materials which are used for a wide range of applications, including mechanical sensing and energy harvesting.

This project addresses the challenge of streamlining process, structure, property, and performance of cast or additively manufactured alloys during solidification
process. The findings provide micromechanical insights on the governing mechanisms of microstructural and porosity evolutions during solidification and different types of AM processes and bridge the process parameters, porosity and morphology of alloys, and their tensile and fatigue properties and mechanical performance together. The transformative understanding acquired in this project paves the way for futuristic design, manufacturing, optimization, and application of lightweight alloys with high strength-to-weight ratios and other enhanced mechanical properties in a time- and cost-effective manner.

Broader Impacts

The majority of alloys are prepared by solidification or different types of AM techniques. The process is decisive in determining and controlling the
properties of the alloys and performances of the components made of them. Thus, with the insights on the process-structure-property-performance relations gained from this research, we will be able to (1) choose an optimal solidification/AM process for an alloy according to its anticipated performances; and (2) define potential applicability of an alloy and assess its performance based on a given solidification process. In addition, the developed multiscale computational framework will lead to time- and cost-effective design and optimization process that the industries (automotive industry, aerospace industry, as well as other metals manufacturing industries) can utilize to obtain better alloys and alloy components.

The DL-based multistage StackGAN method developed in this work paves the way for quantifying the effect of the microstructure stochasticity and/or
uncertainty on the piezoelectric properties. The high controllability to generate the microstructure morphologies opens a new avenue to optimize piezoceramics and their composites to achieve desired piezoelectric and electromechanical properties by searching the microstructure morphologies in the large space. The results will benefit industry because the piezoceramics and piezocomposites have been widely used in transducers, biomedical applications, and other wearable electronics for a wide range of applications including mechanical sensing and energy harvesting. Based on the outcomes of this study, continued research of linking process, structure, property, and performance for AM piezoceramics and piezocomposites is underway, which will lead to guidelines of acquiring those piezoelectric materials with optimal properties by choosing appropriate AM processes and process parameters.


Last Modified: 04/19/2023
Modified by: Tonya W Stone

por.por_txt_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The overarching goal of the project is to acquire a fundamental understanding of the competing mechanisms that govern the porosity nucleation, growth, and migration during directional solidification (DS) process and employ that understanding to identify process-structure-property-performance relations of cast alloys. This goal was accomplished based on analysis and interpretation of existing DS experimental data using tools of computational continuum mechanics, crystal physics, and multiscale modeling.  Specific outcomes of this work are:

A validated multiscale computational framework which includes a FE-based internal state variable (ISV) plasticity model and a FE-based thermal model at the macroscale and a temperature-dependent grain growth phase-field model and fast Fourier transform-based elasto-viscoplastic (EVP-FFT) micromechanical model at the mesoscale for studying and predicting the predict the microstructure evolutions of metallic and ceramic polymer composite materials during additive manufacturing processes.
Using this multiscale framework, process-structure-property relationships of AM-produced Ti-6Al-4V alloy, Al-Si-Mg alloy, and TPC piezocomposite, as well as the precipitation kinetics in INCONEL 625 have been studied in conjunction with necessary experimental investigations.
A novel deep learning (DL) based multistage StackGAN methodology has been developed for the reconstruction of synthetic microstructures of additively manufactured piezoceramics. The developed method is an effective and powerful tool in investigating the structure-property-performance relationship of peizoelectric materials which are used for a wide range of applications, including mechanical sensing and energy harvesting.


This project addresses the challenge of streamlining process, structure, property, and performance of cast or additively manufactured alloys during solidification
process. The findings provide micromechanical insights on the governing mechanisms of microstructural and porosity evolutions during solidification and different types of AM processes and bridge the process parameters, porosity and morphology of alloys, and their tensile and fatigue properties and mechanical performance together. The transformative understanding acquired in this project paves the way for futuristic design, manufacturing, optimization, and application of lightweight alloys with high strength-to-weight ratios and other enhanced mechanical properties in a time- and cost-effective manner.

Broader Impacts

The majority of alloys are prepared by solidification or different types of AM techniques. The process is decisive in determining and controlling the
properties of the alloys and performances of the components made of them. Thus, with the insights on the process-structure-property-performance relations gained from this research, we will be able to (1) choose an optimal solidification/AM process for an alloy according to its anticipated performances; and (2) define potential applicability of an alloy and assess its performance based on a given solidification process. In addition, the developed multiscale computational framework will lead to time- and cost-effective design and optimization process that the industries (automotive industry, aerospace industry, as well as other metals manufacturing industries) can utilize to obtain better alloys and alloy components.

The DL-based multistage StackGAN method developed in this work paves the way for quantifying the effect of the microstructure stochasticity and/or
uncertainty on the piezoelectric properties. The high controllability to generate the microstructure morphologies opens a new avenue to optimize piezoceramics and their composites to achieve desired piezoelectric and electromechanical properties by searching the microstructure morphologies in the large space. The results will benefit industry because the piezoceramics and piezocomposites have been widely used in transducers, biomedical applications, and other wearable electronics for a wide range of applications including mechanical sensing and energy harvesting. Based on the outcomes of this study, continued research of linking process, structure, property, and performance for AM piezoceramics and piezocomposites is underway, which will lead to guidelines of acquiring those piezoelectric materials with optimal properties by choosing appropriate AM processes and process parameters.
